Let's say:

Read *, t

Then read t numbers into an array n_array(1:t). But in Fortran, dynamic arrays can be handled with allocatable arrays. So:

integer :: t, i

integer, allocatable :: n_array(:)

read(*,*) t

allocate(n_array(t))

read(*,*) (n_array(i), i=1,t) Then, take n1 = n_array(1) Compute maxLeft:

max_val = n1 - 2

if (max_val <0) then, set to 0.

Then, compute the binary of max_val and count the 1s.

children.text:
To compute the binary digits and count 1s:

We can do this by repeatedly dividing by 2 and counting the remainder 1s. Initialize count_ones =0

temp = max_val

do while (temp >0)

   if (mod(temp,2) ==1) then

      count_ones = count_ones +1

   end if

   temp = temp /2

end do

Wait, but this counts the number of 1s in the binary representation.

write(count_str, '(i0)') count_ones

trim the string to remove leading spaces.

Now, let's structure the Fortran code. The program will:

children.label: high_level_plan

children.text:
First, the variables:

integer :: t, i, n1, max_val, count_ones, current_length

integer, allocatable :: n_array(:)

character(len=20) :: count_str

character(len=100) :: result_str

current_length =0

Read the input:

read(*,*) t

allocate(n_array(t)) read(*,*) (n_array(i), i=1,t)

n1 = n_array(1) Compute max_val:

if (n1 >2) then

   max_val = n1 -2

else

   max_val =0

end if

Compute count_ones:

count_ones =0

temp = max_val

do while (temp >0) if (mod(temp,2) ==1) then

      count_ones = count_ones +1

   end if

   temp = temp /2

end do

Convert count_ones to string: write(count_str, '(i0)') count_ones

count_str = adjustl(count_str) !
children.label: code_analysis

children.text:
to remove leading spaces, but maybe not needed. Process the string:

result_str = ' '

current_length =0

do i=1, len_trim(count_str)

   character(len=1) :: c = count_str(i:i)

   select case (c)

   case ('0')

      current_length = current_length +1

      result_str(current_length:current_length) = '0'

   case ('1')

      current_length = current_length +1

      result_str(current_length:current_length) = '1'

   case ('B')

      if (current_length >0) then

         current_length = current_length -1

      end if

   case default

      ! do nothing

   end select

end do

Finally, output the result_str up to current_length:

if (current_length ==0) then

   print *, ''

else

   print '(a)', result_str(1:current_length)

end if

Wait, but in Fortran, when using print *, it will output the characters up to the first space.

children.text:
Now, let's write the code step by step. First, the program starts with:

program main

implicit none

integer :: t, i, n1, max_val, count_ones, current_length

integer, allocatable :: n_array(:)

character(len=20) :: count_str

character(len=100) :: result_str

! Read input

read(*,*) t

allocate(n_array(t))

read(*,*) (n_array(i), i=1,t)

n1 = n_array(1)

! Compute max_val if (n1 > 2) then

   max_val = n1 -2

else

   max_val =0

end if

! Compute count_ones

count_ones =0

integer :: temp = max_val

do while (temp >0)

   if (mod(temp,2) ==1) then

      count_ones = count_ones +1

   end if

   temp = temp /2

end do

!
children.label: code_analysis

children.text:
do nothing

   end select

end do

! Output the result

if (current_length ==0) then

   print *, ''

else

   print '(A)', trim(result_str(1:current_length)) end if

deallocate(n_array)

end program main

Wait, but in Fortran, when using result_str(current_length:current_length) = '0', the array must be large enough.
